I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asia Regional Integration Center (ARIC) was established in 2006 by the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  through  its  Office  of  Regional  Economic  Integration  (OREI)  to 
(i) provide access to timely and relevant knowledge and information on regional cooperation and 
integration (RCI), (ii) assist regional economic monitoring and policy dialogue, and (iii) support 
research on RCI.1 Since then, ARIC has helped increase the capacity of key stakeholders in the 
region  to  respond  to  regional  challenges.  Initially,  ARIC  stands  for  the  Asia  Recovery 
Information  Center,  which  was  established  after  the  1997  Asian  financial  crisis  to  provide 
reliable,  timely,  and  accurate  crisis-related  information  to  restore  confidence  and  support 
economic recovery in the region. Later, in March 2004, it was renamed the Asia Regional 
Information Center, providing information on recovery efforts in Indonesia, the Republic of Korea, 
Malaysia, the Philippines, and Thailand; and later extended to cover the People’s Republic of 
China, Singapore, and Viet Nam. In 2006, the newly renamed Asia Regional Integration Center 
was given a new mandate to serve as a one-stop, web-based knowledge and information portal 
on the progress of RCI. ARIC has since grown to become an acknowledged and reliable source 
of RCI information and knowledge. It also supports ADB’s Strategy 2020, adopted in 2008, 
which defined regional integration as one of its three development agenda and RCI as one of its 
core specialization and operational areas.2 
 
2.  The fifth phase of the ARIC technical assistance (TA) will support the “3 Is” agenda of 
innovation, inclusion, and integration, which was highlighted by the ADB President at the 2013 
Annual Meeting. The TA will assist the interplay between the “3 Is” by sharing innovation and 
knowledge through regional dialogue and cooperation, to promote more inclusive growth for the 
region. The TA will build on the success of past phases of the ARIC TA and help ADB analyze 
more complex, new RCI challenges. It will also help formulate concrete policy actions for the 
region  in  dealing  with  the  continuing  global  transformation.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Regional economic integration plays a vital role in improving productivity, accelerating 
economic growth, and reducing poverty. It is thus a welcome development that RCI has gained 
momentum in Asia and the Pacific. For instance, intraregional trade rose from 54.9% in 2000 to 
59.3% in 2010, though it has fallen back to 54.9% in 2012. Free trade agreements (FTAs) 
continue to proliferate—135 FTAs had been concluded by July 2013, up from 46 in 2000. The 
region’s share of total foreign asset holdings also rose from 15.1% in 2008 to 18.5% in 2011. 
  
4.  However, while RCI has advanced since the Asian financial crisis, progress has been 
slow and gradual in many of today’s complex and sensitive RCI areas, such as risk sharing, 
trade in services, labor mobility, and the “noodle bowl effect” caused by proliferation of bilateral 
and regional FTAs.4 Political differences have also undermined RCI progress. After the global 
financial crisis, the region and the world have grown more interconnected and multipolar, and 
Asia stands to gain from strengthening regional ties. In particular, greater regional cooperation

will help Asia’s economies develop more unified positions and policy options in relation to 
advanced and developing economies outside the region. 
 
5.  Asia’s RCI model is unique. Different from Europe or other parts of the world, the region 
has made solid progress in RCI, based on its pragmatic, bottom-up, institution-light, and private-
sector-led  approach.  After  the  2008/09  global  financial  crisis,  advanced  economies  are 
undergoing a prolonged period of structural adjustment and weaker economic growth—a “new 
normal.” This means Asia must become more self-reliant in developing new sources of growth. 
RCI can play a more central role than in the past by easing trade flows, promoting deeper 
financial integration, and creating seamless logistics and infrastructures. Sustained regional 
cooperation may also result in better coordinated macroeconomic, financial, and trade policies 
that help drive a more efficient and welfare-oriented region. Effective cooperation can help 
maximize net benefits and lay the foundation for more inclusive growth. 
 
6.  However, the eurozone sovereign debt crisis also underscores the need to understand 
the costs of greater integration. This is particularly relevant in terms of monetary and financial 
cooperation, where increased uncertainty and finance sector volatility continue to threaten the 
stability of global and regional economies. These key risk factors are important concerns for the 
region—and they need to be tracked, their regional implications considered, and measures to 
mitigate their effects defined.  
 
7.  ARIC holds a unique position to assist RCI, having gained expertise in disseminating 
RCI knowledge and information widely, efficiently, and inexpensively. By providing reliable, 
timely, and accurate information on RCI, ARIC will further help the region understand costs and 
benefits  of  regional  integration.  ARIC  will  also  strengthen  its  collaboration  with  other 
departments of ADB, as well as institutions in the region, in both producing and disseminating 
knowledge on regional economic integration and cooperation.   
 
8.  Over the past 7 years, ARIC has become a reliable source of knowledge and information 
on  RCI.  It  provides  up-to-date  information  on  (i)  RCI-related  studies,  news,  opinions,  and 
editorials on RCI; (ii) indicator databases such as trade integration and FTAs; investment, 
macroeconomic, monetary, and financial indicators; tax incentives; and climate change action 
plans and commitments; (iii) calendars of economic data releases and RCI events; and (iv) early 
warning  system  indicators.  Its  key  publication—the  Asian  Economic  Integration  Monitor 
(AEIM)—has helped policymakers in ADB developing member countries to increase awareness 
and knowledge on RCI trends and issues. The ARIC website and its publications have also 
been recognized by top-tier media like BBC, Bloomberg, CNBC, the Financial Times, Reuters, 
and Wall Street Journal as a reliable source of economic and RCI information. ARIC also 
assists the preparation of the economic prospects and policy issues for ASEAN+3, ADB’s 
contribution to the semiannual ASEAN+3 finance and central bank deputies’ meetings.5 
 
9.  From 1 January to 15 October 2013, the ARIC website has attracted 53,000 unique 
visitors  with  over  439,000  page  views.  Over  440  organizations  ranging  from  multilateral, 
regional, academic, government, media, and private institutions have embedded links to the 
ARIC  website. These  include  the  Association of  Southeast  Asian  Nations;  Bloomberg; the 
Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (Australia); Department of Trade Negotiations 
(Thailand);  East  Asia  Forum;  Harvard  University;  International  Labor  Organization;  Johns 
Hopkins  University;  Monash  University;  National  University  of  Singapore;  Organisation  for 
Economic Co-operation and Development; Reuters; the Southeast Asian Ministers of Education 
Organization; United Nations; University of California, Berkeley; University of Melbourne; Wall 
                                                
5  ASEAN+3 = 10 ASEAN members plus the People's Republic of China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea.

Street Online; World Bank and World Trade Organization. The ARIC website was accessed in 
over 186 countries in 2012, with an average of 5,600 visits from the top 10 countries—the 
People’s  Republic  of  China, India,  Indonesia, Japan,  Malaysia,  the  Philippines,  Singapore, 
Thailand, the United States, and Viet Nam. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  Impact. The impact will be the enhanced implementation of existing RCI initiatives and 
the development of new ones by key stakeholders. The impact will be measured by the number 
intraregional agreements and other forms of cooperation (such as policy dialogue), as well as 
the degree of regional integration as evident from indicators of regional cross-border flows.  
 
11.  Outcome.  The  outcome  will  be  the  increased  utilization  of  ARIC’s  RCI-related 
knowledge products by key stakeholders in Asia and the Pacific.6 The increased usage will be 
measured through the number of media citations and interviews; use of its data and information 
in management speeches and demand from its web-based clients. It is expected that access to 
the ARIC website will grow in line with the average annual growth of its website statistics for 
2006–2012.7 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The  TA  will  produce  and  disseminate  high-quality  RCI  knowledge  products  and 
information to develop the capacity of its stakeholders to promote greater regional integration. 
For this phase, the knowledge work will focus on complex, second generation RCI issues such 
as drivers and “derailers” of RCI, infrastructure connectivity and financing, labor mobility and 
remittances, cooperation between developing countries in Asia, role of the private sector in RCI, 
and special regional economic zones among others. The goal of the knowledge work is to 
create and share innovative ideas, policy options, and regional solutions to pressing RCI issues. 
 
13.  In step with these aspirations, the TA will produce the following outputs: 
 
(i)  Publication of three issues of the AEIM. In addition to providing updates on RCI 
progress,  the  report  will  feature  high-quality  thematic  chapters  on  second 
generation RCI issues. The key RCI indicators in the report will also be made 
available for downloading online. In addition to East Asia and Southeast Asia, the 
report will also emphasize the importance of Central and West Asia, South Asia, 
and the Pacific in the region. 
(ii)  Publication of other RCI-related knowledge products, including 15 issues of the 
RCI information pack, 10 working papers on RCI, and 10 RCI blogs. The RCI 
information pack will report upcoming events across the four pillars of ADB’s RCI 
strategy:  (i)  cross-border  infrastructure  and  related  software,  (ii)  trade  and 
investment, (iii) money and finance, and (iv) regional public goods. It will also 
track key  macro  interdependence  indicators.  The  working  paper  on RCI  will

of RCI.

analyze important regional integration issues, while RCI blogs will provide short 
and punchy articles on key RCI lessons. 
(iii)  Timely and accurate RCI databases with expanded country coverage to include 
India, Kazakhstan and Papua New Guinea. Some enhancements will also be 
made to allow easy downloads of key “takeaway products.” 
(iv)  A more informative and updated website to include a customized view for policy 
makers, researchers, students, media, and civil society. The TA also plans to 
conduct an extensive user survey to identify the strength and weaknesses of the 
website. The feedback will be used to further improve the site. 
(v)  An RCI roundtable to serve as a venue to discuss and share RCI knowledge and 
experiences  by  key  stakeholders  across  the  region.  Three  subregional 
consultations to disseminate RCI knowledge and gather feedback and lessons 
from other subregions—particularly Central and West Asia, South Asia and the 
Pacific—will also be held.  
(vi)  Stronger horizontal support to improve RCI knowledge sharing and coordination 
with regional and other departments in ADB.  
 
14.   As global growth remains tepid and unresolved policy issues in advanced economies 
trigger economic and financial volatility, RCI remains a helpful strategy for the region. RCI can 
help manage the risks from increased interdependence and at the same time maximize the 
benefits from open regionalism. ADB is a leader in this area and the TA supports the ADB’s 
leadership through its three critical functions: 
 
(i)  Serve as a knowledge hub for RCI through its AEIM publication, regional integration 
and  financial  vulnerability  indicators,  and  FTA  databases.  While  the  more 
straightforward  issues  have  been  addressed  in  previous  ARIC  TA  projects,  this 
phase will focus its knowledge work on the more difficult second generation RCI 
issues. 
(ii) Support ADB's participation in regional and/or global forums, such as dialogue with 
APEC,  ASEAN,  ASEAN+3,  and  Asia–Europe  Meeting,  among  others.  A  new 
direction is to go outside of Southeast Asia and work with other regional initiatives 
and institutions to share the lessons and experiences of Southeast Asia. 
(iii) Provide  horizontal  support  to  RCI  work  of  other  ADB  departments  (Regional 
Departments, Economics and Research Department, and Regional and Sustainable 
Development  Department)  and  RCI  Community  of  Practice.  This  TA  envisages 
greater  dialogue  and  consultation to  design  RCI-related knowledge  work that  is 
aligned with ADB priorities and operations. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.   The TA is estimated to cost $1,500,000, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund8 and (ii) $1,000,000 will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-V).  The  detailed  cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
                                                
8  Established by ADB.

5 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the executing agency. OREI will implement the TA in consultation with and 
support from other ADB departments, offices, and communities of practice. The RCI community 
of practice will serve as an advisory committee for TA implementation. The TA will explore the 
possibility  of  collaborating  with  regional  “centers  of  excellence”—Analytical  Centre  on 
Globalization  and  Regional  Cooperation,  Asian  Institute  of  Management,  Climate  Action 
Network,  International  Centre  of  Excellence  in  Asia-Pacific  Studies,  Pacific  Islands  Forum 
Secretariat, the UNESCO Madanjeet Singh Institute for South Asia Regional Cooperation—to 
raise the quality of its implementation. The TA will be implemented over 18 months, from 
December 2013–May 2015.  
 
17.  The  TA  will  require  2  international  consultants  (21  person-months),  20  national 
consultants  (346  person-months),  and  7  resource  persons  (3  person-months).  Individual 
consultants and resource people will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). The scope of work and outline terms 
of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
18.  A team of OREI staff (at least three international staff: one of them acting as the project 
leader, one national officer, and  one operational assistant), assisted by an ARIC principal 
economic analyst (who is a national consultant), will oversee and lead the implementation of the 
TA. International consultants will be hired under the TA—a regional cooperation economist who 
will prepare special studies on RCI and assist in ARIC seminars; and an economics and copy 
editor who will edit ARIC and OREI publications. National consultants will include one principal 
economic analyst who will assist in the supervision of ARIC’s operations, and coordination and 
consolidation of its output; four senior economic analysts who will lead the delivery of ARIC’s 
core services, and 10 economic analysts who will maintain and update the content of the ARIC 
website  and  assist  in  the  preparation  of  ARIC  publications  and  seminars.  Other  national 
consultants include one website developer, one multimedia designer and developer, one system 
and database developer, one typesetter, and one project specialist to provide administrative 
support. Three person-months will be allotted to engage internationally distinguished experts 
who will be invited to be resource persons at RCI seminars. 
 
19.  Purchases of equipment (computer hardware and software) and statistical databases will 
be undertaken in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended from time 
to time) and in coordination with ADB’s Office of Information Systems and Technology and 
Office of Administrative Services. After the TA is completed, all equipment will be disposed of in 
compliance with Administering Grant-Financed Technical Assistance Projects in the Project 
Administration Instructions.9 Disbursement under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis 
for the Asia Regional Integration Center, Phase V, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Regional  cooperation  economist (1 position, international, 6 person-months). The 
economist  will  be  familiar  with  trade,  macroeconomics,  finance,  regional  cooperation  and 
development issues in Asia and the Pacific. The economist will report to Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) staff and, under the supervision of ADB staff, will 
(i)  prepare special studies on agreed topics related to regional cooperation and 
integration (RCI) and revise and finalize the study findings based on comments 
from ADB staff and other consultants; and 
(ii)  draft and edit economic and other reports. 
 
2.  Outputs will include written reports and presentations on special studies regarding RCI 
issues. 
 
3.  Economics and copy editor (1 position, international, 15 person-months). The editor 
should be familiar with economic and development issues in Asia and the Pacific, and have 
strong communication skills. The editor will report to the ADB staff. Under the supervision of 
ADB staff, the editor will  
(i)  edit contents of the Asia Regional Integration Center (ARIC) website, the Asian 
Economic Integration Monitor (AEIM), ADB working papers on regional economic 
integration, management statements, press releases, and technical documents; 
(ii)  examine economic arguments in documents to assess whether they are logical 
and are based on accepted economic theory and principles, and revise them if 
necessary; 
(iii)  examine  and  edit  the  tables  and  figures  in  the  documents  to  ensure  data 
consistency; and  
(iv)  ensure that documents adhere to ADB style and usage and conform to high 
publication standards. 
 
4.  Outputs will include edited content of the ARIC website, management statements, press 
releases, Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) publications and technical documents; 
and written notices to OREI paper authors regarding comments on substance and logic of 
arguments and adherence to ADB style and usage. 
 
5.  Principal economic analyst (1 position, national, 18 person-months). The analyst will 
have sufficient managerial capabilities to perform supervisory tasks; extensive knowledge of 
economic and policy issues in the region; adequate background on database development and 
management;  strong  proficiency  in  data  processing  and  analysis;  familiarity  with  computer 
applications used in economic analysis; and commendable communication skills. The analyst 
will be working on a daily basis at the ADB headquarters and will report to the project leader 
and/or other technical assistance (TA) members. Under the supervision of the project leader 
and/or other TA members, the principal economic analyst will  
(i)  coordinates with other TA members in the absence of the project leader; 
(ii)  assist in the management of the daily operations of the ARIC website;  
(iii)  help the project leader and/or other TA members implement the ARIC work plan; 
(iv)  assist in the supervision of technical work done by ARIC team members; 
(v)  support  the  project  leader  and/or  other  TA  members  in  the  preparation  of 
management reports related to ARIC; 
(vi)  liaise with ADB departments and other stakeholders on ARIC-related matters; 
(vii)  provide research support in the preparation of the AEIM by providing country 
notes and data assistance;

14  Appendix 3 
11.  Typesetter  (1  position,  national,  4  person-months).  The  typesetter  will  lay  out  the 
reports (at least three issues of the AEIM) to be published and convert the files into the required 
format for print and/or online publication. The typesetter will be working on a daily basis at the 
ADB headquarters and will report to the  principal economic analyst and project leader. In 
consultation with and under the guidance of the project leader and/or other TA members, the 
typesetter will  
(i)  design the AEIM cover, lay out the text, tables, and charts of the AEIM in Adobe 
InDesign CS2 and Adobe Illustrator CS2; incorporate revisions to the text, tables, 
and charts; and 
(ii)  convert the Adobe files into PDF files for online and print publication. 
 
12.  Project  specialist  (1  position,  national,  18  person-months).  The  specialist  will  be 
working on a daily basis at the ADB headquarters and will report to the principal economic 
analyst, project leader and/or other TA members. Under the supervision of the project leader 
and/or other TA members, the specialist will 
(i)  coordinate  the  ARIC teams’ schedules and  arrange  appointments, meetings, 
mission travels, and accommodations; 
(ii)  assist  the  team  members  with  all  the  logistical  arrangements  for  meetings, 
conferences,  and  workshops,  where  relevant,  and  manage  all  administrative 
procedures and request forms; 
(iii)  assist in maintaining and organizing the ARIC files comprising reports, computer 
files, and other relevant documents; 
(iv)  manage the databases on contacts and assist in maintaining online databases; 
(v)  assist in collecting and formatting data; and references from the Internet and 
online data sources; 
(vi)  construct  and  organize  the  monthly  economic  calendar  for  use  of  ARIC’s 
economic analysts; 
(vii)  monitor  and  prepare  reports  on  ARIC  business  procedures  and  systems, 
including staff attendance and leave plans; 
(viii)  serve as the supply custodian for the ARIC team; 
(ix)  assist in proofreading, editing, and reformatting of OREI’s working paper series 
on RCI; 
(x)  provide secretarial support and assistance if and when necessary; and 
(xi)  undertake other functions as may be assigned by the project leader and/or other 
TA members. 
 
13.  Resource persons (3 person-months). Resource persons will be engaged to make 
presentations at seminar series on RCI. These consultants will be internationally distinguished 
experts on the four pillars of RCI, specializing on regional cooperation and integration issues, or 
policymakers who are considered prime movers of Asian integration. The resource persons will 
(i)  conduct presentations on the topics assigned to them; and  
(ii)  moderate  and  facilitate  discussion  and  exchanges  of  ideas  among  the 
participants, as well as with other resource persons.
